title: Isle of Dogs puppets
brief_description: There were over 500 dog puppets made for Wes Anderson’s Isle of Dogs (2018), with multiple small pieces going into the fantastical creatures - including real strands of hair for the dog’s coats.

constellations_primary.name: Little, big worlds
constellations_primary.description: Wes Anderson's stop-motion animation film draws on tried-and-true techniques that, despite the rise of computer-generated imagery, still inspire filmmakers and game-makers.

description: The first step in the long process to make a stop-motion dog puppet is to sculpt it in plasticine. That’s then made into a mould, which you need when you’re making over 500 dog puppets like they did in Isle of Dogs (2018). But a mould doesn’t move, so the next step is to build a metal skeleton called an ‘armature’, which uses rods and ball joints to let the animator control the dog’s movements. The dog’s face has a separate armature that controls speech and expressions. The armature goes into the mould, gets covered in silicone, and is then painted and poked with real strands of hair to create the dog’s coat.
